segment.source: Backup the TPM recovery Information to AD DS (Windows 10)
segment.target: Backup the TPM recovery Information to AD DS (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to back up a computer’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) information to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) so that you can use AD DS to administer the TPM from a remote computer.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to back up a computer’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) information to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) so that you can use AD DS to administer the TPM from a remote computer.

segment.source: Backup the TPM recovery Information to AD DS
segment.target: Backup the TPM recovery Information to AD DS

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to back up a computer’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) information to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) so that you can use AD DS to administer the TPM from a remote computer.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to back up a computer’s Trusted Platform Module (TPM) information to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) so that you can use AD DS to administer the TPM from a remote computer.

segment.source: About administering TPM remotely
segment.target: About administering TPM remotely

segment.source: Backing up the TPM owner information for a computer allows administrators in a domain to remotely configure the TPM security hardware on the local computer.
segment.target: Backing up the TPM owner information for a computer allows administrators in a domain to remotely configure the TPM security hardware on the local computer.

segment.source: For example, administrators might want to reset the TPM to the manufacturer’s defaults when they decommission or repurpose computers, without having to be present at the computer.
segment.target: For example, administrators might want to reset the TPM to the manufacturer’s defaults when they decommission or repurpose computers, without having to be present at the computer.

segment.source: You can use AD DS to store TPM owner information for use in recovery situations where the TPM owner has forgotten the password or where you must take control of the TPM.
segment.target: You can use AD DS to store TPM owner information for use in recovery situations where the TPM owner has forgotten the password or where you must take control of the TPM.

segment.source: There is only one TPM owner password per computer; therefore, the hash of the TPM owner password can be stored as an attribute of the computer object in AD DS.
segment.target: There is only one TPM owner password per computer; therefore, the hash of the TPM owner password can be stored as an attribute of the computer object in AD DS.

segment.source: The attribute has the common name (CN) of ms-TPM-OwnerInformation.
segment.target: The attribute has the common name (CN) of ms-TPM-OwnerInformation.

segment.source: Note: The TPM owner authorization value is stored in AD DS, and it is present in a TPM owner password file as a SHA-1 hash of the TPM owner password, which is base 64–encoded.
segment.target: Note: The TPM owner authorization value is stored in AD DS, and it is present in a TPM owner password file as a SHA-1 hash of the TPM owner password, which is base 64–encoded.

segment.source: The actual owner password is not stored.
segment.target: The actual owner password is not stored.

segment.source: Domain controllers running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 include the required AD DS schema objects by default.
segment.target: Domain controllers running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 include the required AD DS schema objects by default.

segment.source: However, if your domain controller is running Windows Server 2008 R2, you need to update the schema as described in AD DS schema extensions to support TPM backup.
segment.target: However, if your domain controller is running Windows Server 2008 R2, you need to update the schema as described in AD DS schema extensions to support TPM backup.

segment.source: This topic contains procedures, some of which are dependent on Visual Basic scripts, to recover TPM information and decommission TPM on remote computers.
segment.target: This topic contains procedures, some of which are dependent on Visual Basic scripts, to recover TPM information and decommission TPM on remote computers.

segment.source: Sample scripts are available, which you can customize to meet the requirements of your environment.
segment.target: Sample scripts are available, which you can customize to meet the requirements of your environment.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Check status of prerequisites
segment.target: Check status of prerequisites

segment.source: Set permissions to back up password information
segment.target: Set permissions to back up password information

segment.source: Configure Group Policy to back up TPM recovery information in AD DS
segment.target: Configure Group Policy to back up TPM recovery information in AD DS

segment.source: Use AD DS to recover TPM information
segment.target: Use AD DS to recover TPM information

segment.source: Sample scripts
segment.target: Sample scripts

segment.source: Check status of prerequisites
segment.target: Check status of prerequisites

segment.source: Before you begin your backup, ensure that the following prerequisites are met:
segment.target: Before you begin your backup, ensure that the following prerequisites are met:

segment.source: All domain controllers that are accessible by client computers that will be using TPM services are running Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2 with the updated schema.
segment.target: All domain controllers that are accessible by client computers that will be using TPM services are running Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2 with the updated schema.

segment.source: Tip: For more info about the schema extensions that are required for a TPM backup in Active Directory domains that are running Windows Server 2008 R2, see AD DS schema extensions to support TPM backup.
segment.target: Tip: For more info about the schema extensions that are required for a TPM backup in Active Directory domains that are running Windows Server 2008 R2, see AD DS schema extensions to support TPM backup.

segment.source: You have domain administrator rights in the target forest, or you are using an account that has been granted appropriate permissions to extend the schema for the target forest.
segment.target: You have domain administrator rights in the target forest, or you are using an account that has been granted appropriate permissions to extend the schema for the target forest.

segment.source: Members of the Enterprise Admins or Schema Admins groups are examples of accounts that have the appropriate permissions.
segment.target: Members of the Enterprise Admins or Schema Admins groups are examples of accounts that have the appropriate permissions.

segment.source: Set permissions to back up password information
segment.target: Set permissions to back up password information

segment.source: This procedure uses the sample script Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs to add an access control entry (ACE) so that backing up TPM recovery information is possible.
segment.target: This procedure uses the sample script Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs to add an access control entry (ACE) so that backing up TPM recovery information is possible.

segment.source: A client computer cannot back up TPM owner information until this ACE is added.
segment.target: A client computer cannot back up TPM owner information until this ACE is added.

segment.source: This script is run on the domain controller that you will use to administer the TPM recovery information, and it operates under the following assumptions:
segment.target: This script is run on the domain controller that you will use to administer the TPM recovery information, and it operates under the following assumptions:

segment.source: You have domain administrator credentials to set permissions for the top-level domain object.
segment.target: You have domain administrator credentials to set permissions for the top-level domain object.

segment.source: Your target domain is the same as the domain for the user account that is running the script.
segment.target: Your target domain is the same as the domain for the user account that is running the script.

segment.source: For example, running the script as TESTDOMAINadmin will extend permissions for TESTDOMAIN.
segment.target: For example, running the script as TESTDOMAINadmin will extend permissions for TESTDOMAIN.

segment.source: Note: You might need to modify the sample script if you want to set permissions for multiple domains, but you do not have domain administrator accounts for each of those domains.
segment.target: Note: You might need to modify the sample script if you want to set permissions for multiple domains, but you do not have domain administrator accounts for each of those domains.

segment.source: Find the variable strPathToDomain in the script, and modify it for your target domain, for example:
segment.target: Find the variable strPathToDomain in the script, and modify it for your target domain, for example:

segment.source: Your domain is configured so that permissions are inherited from the top-level domain object to targeted computer objects.
segment.target: Your domain is configured so that permissions are inherited from the top-level domain object to targeted computer objects.

segment.source: Permissions will not take effect if any container in the hierarchy does not allow inherited permissions.
segment.target: Permissions will not take effect if any container in the hierarchy does not allow inherited permissions.

segment.source: By default, permissions inheritance is set in AD DS.
segment.target: By default, permissions inheritance is set in AD DS.

segment.source: If you are not sure whether your configuration differs from this default, you can continue with the setup steps to set the permissions.
segment.target: If you are not sure whether your configuration differs from this default, you can continue with the setup steps to set the permissions.

segment.source: You can then verify your configuration as described later in this topic.
segment.target: You can then verify your configuration as described later in this topic.

segment.source: Or you can click the Effective Permissions button while viewing the properties of a computer object, then check that Self is approved to write the msTPM-OwnerInformation attribute.
segment.target: Or you can click the Effective Permissions button while viewing the properties of a computer object, then check that Self is approved to write the msTPM-OwnerInformation attribute.

segment.source: To add an ACE to allow TPM recovery information backup
segment.target: To add an ACE to allow TPM recovery information backup

segment.source: Open the sample script Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs.
segment.target: Open the sample script Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs.

segment.source: The script contains a permission extension, and you must modify the value of strPathToDomain by using your domain name.
segment.target: The script contains a permission extension, and you must modify the value of strPathToDomain by using your domain name.

segment.source: Save your modifications to the script.
segment.target: Save your modifications to the script.

segment.source: Type the following at a command prompt, and then press ENTER:
segment.target: Type the following at a command prompt, and then press ENTER:

segment.source: cscript Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs
segment.target: cscript Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs

segment.source: This script adds a single ACE to the top-level domain object.
segment.target: This script adds a single ACE to the top-level domain object.

segment.source: The ACE is an inheritable permission that allows the computer (SELF) to write to the ms-TPM-OwnerInformation attribute for computer objects in the domain.
segment.target: The ACE is an inheritable permission that allows the computer (SELF) to write to the ms-TPM-OwnerInformation attribute for computer objects in the domain.

segment.source: Complete the following procedure to check that the correct permissions are set and to remove TPM and BitLocker ACEs from the top-level domain, if necessary.
segment.target: Complete the following procedure to check that the correct permissions are set and to remove TPM and BitLocker ACEs from the top-level domain, if necessary.

segment.source: Manage ACEs configured on TPM schema objects
segment.target: Manage ACEs configured on TPM schema objects

segment.source: Open the sample script List-ACEs.vbs.
segment.target: Open the sample script List-ACEs.vbs.

segment.source: Modify List-ACEs.vbs.
segment.target: Modify List-ACEs.vbs.

segment.source: You must modify:
segment.target: You must modify:

segment.source: Value of strPathToDomain: Use your domain name.
segment.target: Value of strPathToDomain: Use your domain name.

segment.source: Filter options: The script sets a filter to address BitLocker and TPM schema objects, so you must modify If IsFilterActive () if you want to list or remove other schema objects.
segment.target: Filter options: The script sets a filter to address BitLocker and TPM schema objects, so you must modify If IsFilterActive () if you want to list or remove other schema objects.

segment.source: Save your modifications to the script.
segment.target: Save your modifications to the script.

segment.source: Type the following at a command prompt, and then press ENTER:
segment.target: Type the following at a command prompt, and then press ENTER:

segment.source: cscript List-ACEs.vbs
segment.target: cscript List-ACEs.vbs

segment.source: With this script you can optionally remove ACEs from BitLocker and TPM schema objects on the top-level domain.
segment.target: With this script you can optionally remove ACEs from BitLocker and TPM schema objects on the top-level domain.

segment.source: Configure Group Policy to back up TPM recovery information in AD DS
segment.target: Configure Group Policy to back up TPM recovery information in AD DS

segment.source: Use these procedures to configure the TPM Group Policy settings policy setting on a local computer.
segment.target: Use these procedures to configure the TPM Group Policy settings policy setting on a local computer.

segment.source: In a production environment, an efficient way to do this is to create or edit a Group Policy Object (GPO) that can target client computers in the domain.
segment.target: In a production environment, an efficient way to do this is to create or edit a Group Policy Object (GPO) that can target client computers in the domain.

segment.source: To enable local policy setting to back up TPM recovery information to AD DS
segment.target: To enable local policy setting to back up TPM recovery information to AD DS

segment.source: Sign in to a domain-joined computer by using a domain account that is a member of the local Administrators group.
segment.target: Sign in to a domain-joined computer by using a domain account that is a member of the local Administrators group.

segment.source: Open the Local Group Policy Editor (gpedit.msc), and in the console tree, navigate to Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystem.
segment.target: Open the Local Group Policy Editor (gpedit.msc), and in the console tree, navigate to Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystem.

segment.source: Click Trusted Platform Module Services.
segment.target: Click Trusted Platform Module Services.

segment.source: Double-click Turn on TPM backup to Active Directory Domain Services.
segment.target: Double-click Turn on TPM backup to Active Directory Domain Services.

segment.source: Click Enabled, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Enabled, and then click OK.

segment.source: Important: When this setting is enabled, the TPM owner password cannot be set or changed unless the computer is connected to the domain and AD DS backup of the TPM recovery information succeeds.
segment.target: Important: When this setting is enabled, the TPM owner password cannot be set or changed unless the computer is connected to the domain and AD DS backup of the TPM recovery information succeeds.

segment.source: Use AD DS to recover TPM information
segment.target: Use AD DS to recover TPM information

segment.source: When you need to recover the TPM owner information from AD DS and use it to manage the TPM, you need to read the ms-TPM-OwnerInformation object from AD DS, and then manually create a TPM owner password backup file that can be supplied when TPM owner credentials are required.
segment.target: When you need to recover the TPM owner information from AD DS and use it to manage the TPM, you need to read the ms-TPM-OwnerInformation object from AD DS, and then manually create a TPM owner password backup file that can be supplied when TPM owner credentials are required.

segment.source: To obtain TPM owner backup information from AD DS and create a password file
segment.target: To obtain TPM owner backup information from AD DS and create a password file

segment.source: Sign in to a domain controller by using domain administrator credentials.
segment.target: Sign in to a domain controller by using domain administrator credentials.

segment.source: Copy the sample script file, Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs, to a location on your computer.
segment.target: Copy the sample script file, Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs, to a location on your computer.

segment.source: Open a Command Prompt window, and change the default location to the location of the sample script files you saved in the previous step.
segment.target: Open a Command Prompt window, and change the default location to the location of the sample script files you saved in the previous step.

segment.source: At the command prompt, type cscript Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs.
segment.target: At the command prompt, type cscript Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs.

segment.source: The expected output is a string that is the hash of the password that you created earlier.
segment.target: The expected output is a string that is the hash of the password that you created earlier.

segment.source: Note: If you receive the error message, "Active Directory: The directory property cannot be found in the cache," verify that you are using a domain administrator account, which is required to read the ms-TPM-OwnerInformation attribute.
segment.target: Note: If you receive the error message, "Active Directory: The directory property cannot be found in the cache," verify that you are using a domain administrator account, which is required to read the ms-TPM-OwnerInformation attribute.

segment.source: The only exception to this requirement is that if users are the Creator Owner of computer objects that they join to the domain, they can possibly read the TPM owner information for their computer objects.
segment.target: The only exception to this requirement is that if users are the Creator Owner of computer objects that they join to the domain, they can possibly read the TPM owner information for their computer objects.

segment.source: Open Notepad or another text editor, and copy the following code sample into the file, and replace TpmOwnerPasswordHash with the string that you recorded in the previous step.
segment.target: Open Notepad or another text editor, and copy the following code sample into the file, and replace TpmOwnerPasswordHash with the string that you recorded in the previous step.

segment.source: Save this file with a .tpm extension on a removable storage device, such as a USB flash drive.
segment.target: Save this file with a .tpm extension on a removable storage device, such as a USB flash drive.

segment.source: When you access the TPM, and you are required to provide the TPM owner password, choose the option for reading the password from a file and provide the path to this file.
segment.target: When you access the TPM, and you are required to provide the TPM owner password, choose the option for reading the password from a file and provide the path to this file.

segment.source: Sample scripts
segment.target: Sample scripts

segment.source: You can use all or portions of the following sample scripts, which are used in the preceding procedures, to configure AD DS for backing up TPM recovery information.
segment.target: You can use all or portions of the following sample scripts, which are used in the preceding procedures, to configure AD DS for backing up TPM recovery information.

segment.source: Customization is required depending on how your environment is configured.
segment.target: Customization is required depending on how your environment is configured.

segment.source: Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs: Use to add the access control entry (ACE) for the TPM to AD DS
segment.target: Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs: Use to add the access control entry (ACE) for the TPM to AD DS

segment.source: List-ACEs.vbs: Use to list or remove the ACEs that are configured on BitLocker and TPM schema objects
segment.target: List-ACEs.vbs: Use to list or remove the ACEs that are configured on BitLocker and TPM schema objects

segment.source: Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs: Use to retrieve the TPM recovery information from AD DS for a particular computer
segment.target: Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs: Use to retrieve the TPM recovery information from AD DS for a particular computer

segment.source: Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs
segment.target: Add-TPMSelfWriteACE.vbs

segment.source: This script adds the access control entry (ACE) for the TPM to AD DS so that the computer can back up TPM recovery information in AD DS.
segment.target: This script adds the access control entry (ACE) for the TPM to AD DS so that the computer can back up TPM recovery information in AD DS.

segment.source: List-ACEs.vbs
segment.target: List-ACEs.vbs

segment.source: This script lists or removes the ACEs that are configured on BitLocker and TPM schema objects for the top-level domain.
segment.target: This script lists or removes the ACEs that are configured on BitLocker and TPM schema objects for the top-level domain.

segment.source: This enables you to verify that the expected ACEs have been added appropriately or to remove any ACEs that are related to BitLocker or the TPM, if necessary.
segment.target: This enables you to verify that the expected ACEs have been added appropriately or to remove any ACEs that are related to BitLocker or the TPM, if necessary.

segment.source: Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs
segment.target: Get-TPMOwnerInfo.vbs

segment.source: This script retrieves TPM recovery information from AD DS for a particular computer so that you can verify that only domain administrators (or delegated roles) can read backed up TPM recovery information and verify that the information is being backed up correctly.
segment.target: This script retrieves TPM recovery information from AD DS for a particular computer so that you can verify that only domain administrators (or delegated roles) can read backed up TPM recovery information and verify that the information is being backed up correctly.
